description.text: It is a mounting platform to use a 60mm 15-LED angel eye light around the Rostock Max v2 hotend. It snaps onto the hotend platform in 3 places to hold the LEDs in place. The squirrel cage layer fan mount will not fit with this light ring! I will be designing a new one here soon that uses a 30mm fan. See it work: https://youtu.be/C1I-3bAwU-U Edit 3/18/2016: The clips are very fragile and after taking it off and on they have snappped on me. I can't really beef them up because there is no room, so I secured them with small zip ties around the carriage tabs and it works fine that way.

Print with ABS with 100% infill.  I had to go real slow (20mm/s) so the snap hooks printed properly.  It is designed to hold a 60mm LED angel eye light. Attach the light to the printed part with some RTV, let cure and then attach to the printer and complete the wiring.

comments.text: Where did you plug these in? Separate power supply or straight onto the RAMBo?
comments.author: rdefrancisco2310

comments.text: I wanted the option to turn them on/off at my discretion, so I ran 2-20awg wires from the hotend carriage, up through the split loom and down the x-axis extrusion. I then took the ground wire and soldered it to a ground on the power supply and ran the positive to a 2 pole rocker switch with the power supply + wire on the other pole of the rocker switch so the switch actuates the lights on/off. This is the bracket I made that incorporates a voltmeter and switch: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1421639

These are insulation covers for the aluminium "wings" of the Simple Metal heated bed upgrade, to reduce heat loss.  
After installing the heated bed, I noticed that the black “wings” got quite warm, they acted as heat sinks and radiators, even with the delrin pieces in the kit that were supposed to insulate the “wings” from the machined print plate. It probably has some effect, but a lot of heat is lost that way still.   
It seemed like a good idea to put covers over the wings to reduce the heat loss. I did that by designing hollow PLA wing covers. They are designed as solid parts, but printed with “hollow” infill and 0.8 mm skin. The parts should be hollow since air is a good heat insulator.  
With the insulation I can reach 60C bed temperature in 4-5 minutes and 100C in 19-20 minutes.  
Note that the photo shows a small rectangular hole on the left which is not in the uploaded model. The large rectangular hole is to allow access to the X belt tensioner. The smaller rectangular hole was not required and therefore removed in the model.

Print the STL file with “hollow” infill and 0.8 mm skin. The parts should be hollow since air is a good heat insulator. They can be printed with PLA.  
If you for some reason have an issue with the fit, an OpenSCAD is included.

author: Takeaway3DTech

description.text:
I couldn't find a printable U-joint for Deltabot rods that I liked, so I made one. The bearings give the joint high load capacity with low friction and zero wear.  
Yes, it could be much smaller with special bearings (like the Kossel Pro U-joints) but 623zz is a common and cheap size that fits M3 hardware.   
The rod pocket is sized for TriDPrinting.com 5.8mm rods, but feel free to modify the size to fit whatever you want.  
I will be posting up-rev'd files for overall size and range of motion as I iterate the design. No promises that different revs work together.

Print two of each part. I recommend high infill, 0.5mm extrusion width, 0.2mm layer height, with ABS, but use whatever you want. Bed leveling is very important for the "inner" pieces to get a snug and square fit.  
Add four 623 bearings to the bearing pockets. They should be a snug fit on a well-calibrated printer.   
Hold the two inner pieces bottom to bottom, and press the 3mm shaft into the bearings on the outer halves. Press together the two outer halves. Again, they should be a snug fit on a well-calibrated printer.   
Fasten the two outer halves with a 30mm long M3 screw. I recommend using washers and a lock-nut, but do what you want.  
Epoxy the rod into the U-joint socket using two of the included jig screwed to a piece of 2020 to ensure all rods are the same length.

comments.author: cyde

comments.text: It's pretty self-explanatory once you have the parts in front of you. Print two inner yoke pieces and two outer yoke pieces. Stick four bearings into the bearing pockets. Take the two inner yoke halves, and put them face-to-face (ie print bed side together). Stick the protruding shaft nub into a bearing for one side of the outer yoke. Repeat with the other outer yoke. Then either glue or bolt the two outer yoke halves together around the rod.

comments.text: My thought is that the added stiffness because it's a U-joint and not a spherical joint should offset the extra weight. But I need to build a bot around it to find out!
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text: Hmm, you're right, I hadn't considered that aspect -- I was only comparing it to the original rostock rod-ends, which only have the weight of a bunch of screws and nuts in addition to a smaller volume of plastic than this piece.
comments.author: tempo502

comments.text: I like the Delta-Pi approach, it's a good mechanism as long as the parallelogram joints are colinear with the axis of the carriage rotary joints. That's necessary for the effective rod length to be constant as the arms move through their range of motion. I considered going that way (and still might) but I have a specific application in mind that requires this traditional Cardan-joint style U-joint design.
comments.author: hyperair

comments.text: Each joint weighs about 15g, versus 3g for a traxxas joint plus 20mm M4 set screw, so you're adding ~70g to the effector in total with six rods. My current traxxas joint effector w/ E3Dv6 and blower fan (sans rods) is about 120g. So yeah, it could be a meaningful amount of extra weight. Still pretty light compared to a direct-drive extruder motor though.

description.text: Busts from The Real Ghostbusters cartoon series. There are two versions, the original is just a plane cut just above the waste, the other one has plane cuts removing the arms as well. I did this so I could get a bit more height from the build on my mini.

These were scanned while learning how to use a NextEngineHD scanner and its autotilt base. They were likewise worked in Netfabb, meshlab, and finished in Makerbot desktop.   
The glasses on the original were off-centered and the scanning missed some of the bits, This is a terrible novice sculpting of them for the upload. Hopefully sharing will get some nice prints and some people that are more experienced at editing than I am. Enjoy!   
The prints are of the file before I fixed the glasses, it was printed with supports and more came out than I had figured. The new file should take care of them, no sweat.

This is the first thing I have designed for 3D printing. I used Sketchup to design it.   
It is a little basket/box/container that I designed to hang on a piece of furniture at our house. I measured the furniture with calipers, wrote down the measurements, and created the design.  
One of the next things I want to design is a yogurt cup holder. As I was thinking about this, I looked at the model I had printed and went, hmmmm.  
I put the empty yogurt cup with a spoon in it in the basket and it didn't fall over like it usually does by itself. I may still design something separate, but for now it does the job!

This was printed on my Makerbot Replicator 2X using red ABS plastic. I used the medium profile in makerware and set the infill to 20%. I set to use a raft but no supports. I used the default setting of the right extruder of my printer.  
I exported to x3g file which I copied to the  micro SD card and plugged into the printer and printed it!

This is a cable cam mount assembly designed to enable your GoPro, Sony or other action camera run across a a tensioned line.
The design consists of two wheels and a body made to fit regular “608.” ball bearings with an 8mm core, a 22mm outer diameter and 7mm width. These ball bearings a widely used on skate board, roller skates or kick bikes. The assembly also consists of a small clip used for safety and a GoPro-style mount. Edit 2015-05-29
Made some small updates to the design. I made the base the same width as the camera mount. I also made the safety clip more secure by snapping around the corner of the base. Tip!
Use a piece of rubber foam piece on the end of the line as a break/dampener.

author: smbteacher

description.text: A hook with a bearing to suspend a basket of plastic to feed a RepRap machine. Full details in my blog: http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2008/11/sky-hook.html

Print the plastic parts. Make sure the plastic is hot enough to not de-laminate under tension. You don't want it to drop a few Kg of plastic onto your machine! I recommend 240C for ABS and HDPE. Cut the support membrane out of the large hole in the housing with a penknife.
Thread the barbs through a 608 skate bearing by crossing them over each other. Insert the locking piece and drop the bearing into the housing. Screw it into a ceiling joist.
Note that the close up pictures show a three screw hole housing but the STL file has a two hole version more suitable for ceiling joists.

comments.text: genius!
comments.author: GEARHED01

comments.text: It works really well, but the hook part didn't fit very well. The barbs were nearly impossible to get through the bearing (which I'm sure is intentional). After I got it in though one of the legs snapped. I guess I over-stressed it while cramming it through. I had shaved the barbs down a little and it still bearly fit.  I mangled the second one worse, but it hasn't broken... yet.
comments.author: kitsu

comments.text: To get the legs through the bearing easier, stick it on a hot plate at approx 40C for a few seconds so it softens, then quickly bend and insert.  ABS never snapped on me, but i had a PLA prints hook snap.

author: Tcorgard

title: Replicator 2X Dial Indicator Holder for Mitutoyo

description.text:
• Remix from furicks - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:81430. I have narrow the slot for the Mitutoyo dial indicator - Model: 2046S. Now the slot is tightly fitted without any support for the stem.
    • The L shape was made precisely by furicks. But lacking of photos to illustrated the mounting location. Personally, I found that the holder has the best orientation as it is the closest to the extruder. Hence, the levelling could cover most of the area of your platform. Nonetheless, the mounting has to be side way and watch over from the side while pressing the jog mode. Be very careful not to travel the -Y axis too much towards the front as the probe will extend, knock the dial and caught under the heated bed.

You have to unscrew the left extruder's fan and remove the spacer.   
I printed it with 10% infill, 0.25 layer height. Place it like a L shape on the platform and I did use the support option for the slot.

title: Shark Rocket Vacuum Accessory Retainer Clip

description.text:
Isn't it annoying when you can't find the accessory tools that attach to your vacuum cleaner?  You know you put them in a box, and put the box in a closet, but you just don't remember where they are.  I recently bought a Shark Rocket vacuum and I really like it because it takes up very little space in my tiny workroom.  But there was no way to keep the accessories with the vacuum so they would not get lost.  So I designed a clip to keep them attached to the main tube/wand.   I printed three of them in silver PLA.   
Update: June 2017 - Clips are still working well after two years.  I have heard that PLA can creep if kept under tension, but the ones I have on my Shark clip around the indented part of the accessories, so they are not under stress except for the brief instant when you clip them on.   If you use this for parts where they will be under constant stress, you might want to use PETG or ABS.

The smaller diameter side of the clip attaches to the main tube/wand, and the larger diameter side clips onto the concave area on each accessory tool.   I sliced this using Slic3r, and I used .6mm extrusion width with minimum perimeters = 5, and zero infill.   This forced Slic3r to use extra perimeters to fill in the area in the center where the large and small C-shapes meet.   This makes for a smoother print with less stringing than using other infill patterns.

title: Elder Scrolls V Skyrim loading screen models as Figurines

description.text:
Loading Screen Models Series. tested some but not all of them, at around 1-2 inch figurine size. any bigger should work fine. the hex bases should be easily removable in any 3d software, but they help support the models and normalize the scaling. the spriggan is a bit tricky because of all the small branches. may work on more or other skyrim related parts. leave suggestions if you have any and enjoy some skyrim figurines.  
these are not all custom models. bethesda did all the work i just modified them to be printer friendly. i'm not looking to make money off this. please don't sue me, bethesda. write me a nice email first to give me a warning and i'll happily cower away and take the models down if you have a problem with this.

comments.text: if i wanted to print these at a 20mm size. What is the best way? Cura seems to be missing parts like the necks, and weapons. Would 20mm even work? thanks these look awesome BTW
comments.author: supersoulman

comments.text: repetier is al little more complicated but the new version has a repair function that should solve that
comments.author: supersoulman

comments.text:
I'm having some troubles printing things with hanging parts (most of them). if I add supports it gets almost incredibly hard to give a good finish to the figure, if I don't, well, the hanging parts will fall.
Any of you have some advices to help me.
was using Cura and Slic3r to do the slice.
comments.author: Thunderpombo

comments.text: hi. if its a particular piece, you can import the model into a program like 3ds max, then export just the hanging piece, print out both, then use a soldering/hot glue gun without glue to melt the pieces together (be careful and make sure to clean the tool off after it cools a bit). if the piece is really small (like the draugr arrows) then you may have to scale it up or find a higher res printer to use. you could also try modifying the model in a program like 3ds max to beef up the particular piece (like making really thick arrows) and re exporting as stl. i did try that already but i still wanted to balance the beefing up with the original look so it could be thickened more if necessary
comments.author: Thunderpombo

comments.text: I am having issues printing a few of these. the spriggan and the dragonpriest mostly. the giant, werewolf, troll, and armor came out beautifully tho
comments.author: JRCP1991

comments.text: depending on the scale, some parts may be too thin for your printer's resolution. if you dont want to print at a higher scale, you can open these in a 3d modeling program, add some thickness or a small block around the trouble area to remedy that, re-export as obj or stl, and reprint with the thickened part, then try sanding it to blend with the rest. although they would still be extremely fragile. ive had issues printing the arrows on the draugr but at a certain point, they stop being arrows and are just rods in his back so its a tradeoff of detail to strength and printability. desktop printing tech just isnt there yet. sorry.

comments.text: i'll give those a try when i get my computer working, as well as the rest of the loading screen models, since i also had a request for the shrines. basically the process involves grabbing models from the game or finding them online, bringing them into 3ds max, possibly separating the models into individual pieces for better control, using a shell modifier on the pieces to add thickness, exporting the whole thing as a single stl, then sending it to a free microsoft service that checks for holes in the new models and caps them if necessary. i download the "fixed" models and then upload them here.

title: Improved Pulley with lower slippage and better guidance

description.text:
• Two levels of clamping
  • calculated tolerances for printing included
  • possibility of balancing
  • better belt guidance
    • Additional parts needed:
    6 Nuts M3
    6 screws M3 x 10

• print it
  • rework holes
  • make nut bins free by using soldering iron
  • press nuts in it
  • center nuts by hitting with a drift punch
  • slightly turn screws in
  • put it over the axis in same height as spanners
  • seize scews while centering pulley onto axis
  • loosen slightly screws of original arm hold
  • remove top holder of left side back guidance to get slight gliding
  • span belt without bigger force
  • run in axis

title: Paper Towel Key improved for easier printing

description.text:
Our custodian asked me to cad this out for him because he never had enough of these things.  I tried using Entomophile's design but it didn't quite fit our dispensers here and the file wasn't as printer-friendly as I wanted.  This model should work with any of the squiggly-shaped San Jamar towel dispensers.  
Use this key's awesome power only for good; with great power comes great responsibility.
Just print it laying down flat with a couple shells and enough fill to make it solid.  You shouldn't need any supports.

So i decided to make a new one but in mixed material with a metal ring that guarantee an higher resistance and better visual impact.

I thought that they were perfect for my scope but I need to bend it in a circular shape so I decide to build a roll bender ... and the story can be read here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:835165 This is bent "by hands" with an approximate diameter of 170mm The two lower arms are made with pieces of M4 threaded bar

title: Custom Fan Ducts for CraftBot with circular cross section air nozzle

description.text:
This is a modified version of "CraftBot Custom Fan Ducts" from 3DForms, many thanks to him for the idea. I am hoping that it will improve bridging performance of CraftBot. Here is the modification highlights:
  • 1.4mm lower height, gives 0.9mm margin above E3D nozzle
  • 5mm wide robust connections to 40x40mm fans
  • Circular cross section air nozzle, matching left-right ducts. This is going to blow air evenly, no matter which direction the head moves
  • Circular fan mount
    • Update:
  • Added CB_Fan_Duct_Both_with_Raft.stl for ABS printing with build in raft structures that you can cut afterwards.

Printed with CraftWare v1.10:
  • 0.395mm extrusion width (to properly slice side walls)
  • 50mm/s draw speed
  • 0.15mm layer height
  • 80% perimeter width
  • 40% perimeter speed (20mm/s)
  • 90% 1st layer extrusion adjustment
  • 20mm/s 1st layer speed
  • 215C filament temperature
  • no support needed
    • Print time: <2h
    Filament: <4.5m ABS:
  • 0.35mm extrusion width (to properly slice side walls)
  • 40mm/s draw speed
  • 0.15mm layer height
  • 80% perimeter width
  • 40% perimeter speed (20mm/s)
  • 90% 1st layer extrusion adjustment
  • 20mm/s 1st layer speed
  • 3x top/bottom layers
  • 30% infill
  • 250C filament temperature
  • no support needed
    • Print time: <2.5h
    Filament: <4.0m

author: Corporal_Cow

title: Bed Levelling/Height adjusting screw/clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I use this on the Printrbot simple. It could be used on other machines, the metalwork may need adapting..
I use it with Jon Lawrence, Printrbot Simple X upgrade, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:257841
I needed a convienient way to adjust the height/level of the bed. The arrangement needed to fit my current set up, hold the heat bed, and allow for easy removal and replacement of the bed itself.
The Z-probe never worked consistently for me, so I came up with this solution.
Went for 4 points rather than 3, to maintain rigidity.
Hopefully the pictures tell the story, and see instructions. I am so happy with this, I now have control back to level my print bed!!
19/06/2015, I am very pleased with this now, so removed Work in Progress. See last couple of pics to see flatness. Once you have a flat, level, bed, the rest is a formality

Instructions
Moved the probe up, out the way, but left it there, as I may want to come back to it, it's doing no harm at the moment.
My G-code is now............
G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops
G28 Z0 ;Home Z
;G29 ;Auto Level
Had to reconnect the Z endstop switch.
So no firmware changes necessary. But I did a
M212 X0 Y0 Z0
just in case. The Y Bars, 200x20x2mm, I had these lying around, you could use these...
http://www.screwfix.com/p/door-connectors-zinc-plated-19-x-2-5-x-190mm-pack-of-10/60594
You could get away with anything between, 10 to 30mm width, the length really only needs to be 150mm. The X Bars, see drawing for B length calculation, width again anything from 10 to 30mmm thickness nominally 2mm.
I used these...
http://www.toolstation.com/shop/Construction+Materials/d210/Builders+Metalwork/sd2797/Light+Duty+Strap+Bend/p83370
You could use this for the Y Bars too.
The long screws M3x20mm long, held with nut. The short screw, M3x12mm, is a guiding pin, not the best thing to use as it can catch, so, I filled mine, to smooth off the thread, and this allowed the printed part to ride up and down, without catching.
The B distance is fairly critical, make it a tad longer if necessary, so the bed can sit in, if it's too short you will have to file bits off later, or, you could do what I did, and make the 4mm holes more like slots, using a needle file, this allowed me to adjust for correct fit.
Having attatched the Y Bars with screws, prepare the thumb screw it has a nut inserted into it, I used a screw to pull it in, and then removed the screw. Put the screws in the X Bars and add the printed clips with thumb screws. The printed clip, needed the through hole to be cleaned with a 3mm drill. Clean the other hole with a needle file too, to ensure smooth riding.
I have since, added a small spring under each of the printed clips, on the screw that holds the thumb wheel, this helps avoid any slack between the nut and screw.
I used doublesided tape to hold the X Bar to the Y Bar together, this has been more than adequate for me, see pictures.
Next I added strips of wood, length will depend on your B length, 10 x 5mm, these sit in the clips, I added support for printing, this should snap out easily. These strips of wood are for the heat bed to sit on. Later on, once I had got the position right, I used electician tape to hold it in place, .. not strictly necessary, but it stopped it moving about when I remove the print bed.
Then I added the glass sheet. Here in the UK we have a shop called Poundland, they sell these
http://www.poundland.co.uk/home-and-garden/kitchen/food-preparation/glass-work-top-saver
I cleaned mine up with a wire scourer. They are perfect for print beds. 297 x 197 x 4mm
Using spring clips, attach glass to the wings of the printed clip. .. Looks like they have sold out of these on the web site, I found them still available in local store.
With M3 screws, one rotation of the thumb screw is 0.5mm, there are 10 notches on the thumb screw.
There are many threads on the Printrbot talk forum on how to level a bed manually.
http://www.printrbottalk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=3168&p=21025&hilit=how+to+level+bed#p21025
I like to have a sheet of graph paper under the glass too. You will loose about 10mm Z height, but there are ways to reduce this if necessary, by placing the x bars under the y bars, (2mm saved,) instead of drilling the bars 4mm, you could drill 2.5mm, and tap the holes 3mm, (3mm saved,) you will have to be accurate with your drilling, lastly, you could use the shorter version of the clip, I have printed this, and it seems fine, but I have not used it in my configuration, (3.5mm saved). The loss of height has not been a problem for me.

author: bres55

title: Z-Axis Vibration Dampener for Robo3D R1 (8MM Smooth Rods)

description.text:
My R1's Z-axis smooth rods tended to vibrate in the oval-shaped holes in the top of the case.  
Originally put some rubber bands on the smooth rods to cut down on vibration.  
Had a small sample of semiflex, so designed and printed some vibration dampeners.  
Could probably also be printed in regular ninjaflex, or anything that has a flexible property to it.
Slide them into the oval-shaped holes at the top of your unit and then carefully slide the case on, aligning the smooth rods with the holes in the material.

comments.text: Interesting.  Mine came with a flexible piece just like this that was also printed straight from Robo.  Wonder if Robo started supplying these on stock machines because of all of the complaints with vibration.  I may have to print a couple spares in case I misplace one.  Thanks.

description.text: Made this for my 7 year old brother. He wanted a "ninja star where the blades pop out". It has a really nice action. If you actually wanted to throw it, you might make it out of Delrin which is less brittle than acrylic.

I cut the parts out of .1" acrylic. I glued the "x" shaped handles onto the two large disks with a little acetone. I put two layers of packing tape on the small round spacer so that the blades had a little more clearance. The pins are pieces of 3/32 welding rod I had laying around. I just cut them to size and press fit them into the holes on the blades. I found that the laser tapers the holes a little, so it is easier to push the rod through starting from the wider side of the holes. Each blade has two pins, one protruding from each side of the blade (check out the images and video for more clarity). Everything is held together using a 3/4" 6-32 nut and bolt. You could lock-tight it, but I have mine just finger tight and it stays together. Check out the video of it working:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CGRZURvKpYs
It makes a great desk gadget!

description.text:
Here's a calibration tester that tests overhangs with the 43 degree angle ellipse, filament retraction with the 2 small circular pillars, X & Y accuracy with the triangle and sharp corners and curves. It also tests for warping. Use this with your print settings for the plastic being used to fine tune your 3D printer! Note:
I would suggest scaling the size down if you want to print this relatively quickly; it took around 1 hour to print this calibration tester.

I used a MakerGear M2 to print this calibration test. Here are the settings I used: Settings:
1.7mm layer height
100% speed for the cooling fan
Use Raft & Skirt
53% Infill
NO Support material
4500 mm/min print speed

author: pekrimen

description.text:
This is a rare type of print, it did not start out as an stl file, or evan as an openscad file instead all of its gcode is generated via python. The entire rocket is described only mathematically via algorithms written by Rylan Grayston. We did this to eliminate errors that may be part of the normal sliceing process. We have had great results! and the script generates ten thousand layers in about 1 second. more fun like this can be found on github:
https://github.com/Rylangrayston/gcodeWriters all of our prints that you see here were done with the standard 100 dollar peachy printer kit. The rocket in the pictures is 10 cm tall and has 10000 layers. Like most peachy printer prints it has 100 layers per mm. NOTE: the scad file really just contains python... thingivers wont let me have only a .py file lol
Just a T Slot nut designed because I needed a bunch of them and the metal ones are expensive.  Works well with M5 screws.
Just print it flat with a couple shells and a decent fill level.  Each nut needs a thin 5mm hex nut in order to work.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro Power Supply (Mean Well NES-350-24) Beefcake Fan Shroud Upgrade

description.text:
NOTE: The printer will need to be lifted up about 0.5" off the supporting surface. This mod will not leave any room for airflow with the stock feet (e.i. print upgraded feet or put some 0.5" blocks under the stock rubber support feet).
This fan shroud allows the installation of two 92mm fans in a Mean Well NES-350-24 power supply.  
My printer is installed in an enclosure with elevated ambient air temperature so I needed to increase the forced convection through my printer's power supply.  
These fans (ARCTIC F9 TC - 92 mm Standard Low Noise Temperature Controlled Case Fan) are also much quieter than the single small fan that comes stock on the power supply.

This is a QAV250 version of my landing gear that I made for a friend.  It clips onto the arms in whatever position you want them in.  It places the main plate 43mm off the ground giving you about 3cm of ground clearance.  Enough to land safely in grass, probably even with angled motor mounts.  These are super easy to work with as they just clip on and off your arms.  A little bit of filing is likely required after printing to make them fit well(depending on your printer)  Once printed and installed they should grip the arm well enough that you can pick up your QAV250 by one of the landing struts without it moving.(again, depends on your printer and print material.  (we use PLA and PETG)  
I will add a picture when I can,

comments.text: I made 8 of them, unfortunately all of them broke after medium hard landing. I will try a last time with 100% infill, but otherwise I cannot recommend these landing gears.
comments.author: Camperinho

comments.text: We make ours out of PETG and see a huge difference in strength depending on how we print them and what printer we use.  We don't use these if we are racing or crashing a lot, there aren't any designs that can really stand up to that kind of abuse unless you go really low profile.  For me, I used the landing gear to save my props while I was learning, now that I don't crash unless I crash bad I generally fly without gear on.  Thank you for your feedback.  One of these days I need to make some low profile pads that will take abuse and keep holding together.
comments.author: Camperinho

author: flipmil

description.text: This is based on a standard block from our lab. The two large holes accommodate 50mL tubes. The next size down handles 15mL tubes. The two smaller sizes are for centrifuge tubes, depending on how low and tight you want your tubes to fit and how many slots you need. We like to have a lot of these laying around so I'll probably print 10-12 before I'm done.

I'm planning to try printing this with my Cupcake CNC. It will probably need to be re-centered in ReplicatorG. I will update with results when I have them. FYI, the standard Cupcake build platform is too small to accommodate the model.

comments.text: Not to imply in any way that cost effectiveness should necessarily be a driver of this sort of thing, but I'd still be interested to know how much they cost printed as opposed to buying them from VWR / Fisher. Do you havea feel for that?
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text: I checked with our VWR rep. Catalog price is $63. Our contract price is $40. They're willing to sell it to me for $30. There is no bulk discount for buying a pack of 5 or 10. That's a much bigger markup than I expected for such a simple device. Printing 10 of these would easily pay for the time that I spent in Google Sketchup designing it.
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text: I'll check on our contract price with VWR on Monday, I don't know it right off hand. I'm printing an 80% scale model right now and ReplicatorG says it will use 40ccs of plastic. I don't have a feel for how much that is yet in terms of poundage, but I imagine it's under $1. Plus $1 worth of electricity to run the bot for 2.5 hours (also an estimate). If VWR was in the business of selling raw plastics, I'm sure their logistics and inventory overheads would be almost nothing. Since they sell everything for labs, I'm thinking their markup on this thing will be 80%+.
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text:
Hello! 50g of filament is about $1.
Though you can find similar racks on eBay for around $6-$7. eBay is a great source of inexpensive lab supplies, compared to those ridiculously overpriced lab supply companies.
I might print out one of these for fun though.What do you do about supports? No matter how you print it, you can't avoid overhangs.

Updated tipping bucket, created in OpenSCAD.  This version uses straight edges instead of rounded to save on plastic.

• Print the part
  • Drill the hole out to fit some kind of rod, I used aileron control rod from a hobby shop threaded for about 1/2 inch from one end and smooth for the rest cut to length
  • Epoxy a magnet at whatever location is convenient to trigger a reed switch
  • Drill a hole in a CD spindle through the center spindle to bolt on your rod
  • Add a funnel to the CD spindle's lid and point it at the center of the tipping bucket
  • Connect the reed switch to a micro controller and do some math to calculate rain fall. rainfall = <# of tips> * /
  • Profit

title: DIY Mixing Station (24 bottles) for Vaporizor e-juice (Vape, vapelife, vapegear)

description.text:
Created this after receiving my wizard labs order for 24 concentrates. The spot in front of each holds a 15mL MBV bottle that I use for diluting the concentrate, with a few syringe holders in the front, spots for 2 recipes, and a little square spot for random things, lids, etc.   
Took 7 hours to print with 12-15% infill. You can probably just print it with no infill for a quicker print.   
The Concentrates fit pretty snug in there and makes a great station to keep everything organized. Will be uploading a larger one with no dilution spots once the next order comes in. :)   
Enjoy (post your build pics!)

title: Zelda's Bow with lights
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is Zelda's bow from Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess and from Smash Bros. It uses neopixels and Arduino for lighting effects. Everything is held together with magnets.  
The zip file contains all of the STL files. There were a lot, so I didn't attach each individually.

All of the STL files are available in the attached ZIP file, along with the Arduino code. This instructable shows how to build the bow:
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-make-Zeldas-Bow/

description.text: 5-16-2011 I have updated the files so that the parts are 3mm thick. This makes a more stable Dino. Please Enjoy. Well I've been hopeing that someone would make one of these. Seeing that no one did, I decided to get off my butt and make one myself. I hope others will have some fun with it as well. I used this dino as my insperation, and then traced the plans in Sketchup. http://www.epiloglaser.com/sc_dino.htm I don't Know who the creater is, but I would like to say thanks for the plans.

I made the files to fit my Mendal Pursa, but you can rearange them or scale them to fit whatever you want.
Print all the parts and then assemble them like a puzzle. The current scale will print at 2mm thick, which will stand up on it own just fine. If I print it again, I will probably make it a little thicker. I will also have to make the slots wider if I do.

title: 3 Part - Micro Hexacopter (with zip tie slots)

description.text:
This is a remix of TJWeb's 3 part micro hexacopter. Thank you TJWeb for the base model!  
I added zip tie slots to hold the 3 parts together. I did this to keep the parts from sliding up or down during flight. Glue does the job but makes it impossible to replace a part after a hard crash.

You will need to print three of the four parts.  
Hex-Right.stl, Hex-Left.stl and then either Hex-Rear.stl or Hex-Rear-36mm.stl.  
The 36mm flavor includes standoffs at the 30.5mm spacing for a 36mmx36mm flight controller such as the Naze32 and many others.  
I am printing mine right now using ProtoPasta CF reinforced PLA. I will add pictures when it is complete.

comments.text: Not printed it yet(soon), but i would use more/thicker ties, are those really enough?

In Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder, fantasy, science fiction, and cosmic horror combine into a sprawling multiverse where nearly anything is possible. Grounded with an intuitive RPG system designed with foundations in real-world physics, Wayfarer allows players and GM's to create the characters and stories they want right out of the gate. The Wayfarer rules codex is available for purchase on our website, illgottengames.net

comments.text: As a design choice, why do you make 2 part bases? The printer settings already make them hollow...
comments.author: drxenocide

comments.text: Well, at a 3mm height (standard for this scale), you get topological holes without setting support structures or using infill. Ends up using the least amount of plastic, doesn't require any glue, and get's the cleanest detail results.
comments.author: drxenocide

author: dutchmogul

title: Cover for Type I or Type II Hitch Receiver

description.text: I scaled down Stimpy's hitch cover, which is for a 2" square receiver (Class III or IV), to fit a Class I or II receiver, which is only 1-1/4" square.  The prongs are now just a smidge too "short" to pop perfectly into the holes on the receiver, due the scaling I'm sure, but it still works great.  I also dressed up the one that I actually printed with some Jeep badging, as it will be going on my Wrangler.  Sketchup Make.

The photo isn't great, but I'm pleased with the way it turned out.  Used glow-in-the-dark PLA, because that's all I have.  Printed face-down (with support, due the badging protruding a bit; probably should've made it 'concave' and I wouldn't have had to screw around with any support) at .3mm resolution, 30% infil.  Took about 50 minutes or so.

comments.text: Any idea exactly how short the prongs are? It'd be nice to adjust the design so they fit snugly.
comments.author: hansen_m

author: Poguey44

description.text:
RAM mount for GoPro.
Printing will be for tomorrow. Going to print with 5 perimeters, 5 top and bottom solid layers and 80% infill for strength. [edit] The mount has been printed. Little sanding needed after removing the support material. Fits very well in the RAM arm.
Next: strength test but that could take a while since only my track bike has a RAM mount.
[Strength test] After 5 sessions on the race track with my Ducati 999 the Gopro mount was still in 1 piece. I think that's a success. :)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cQ6GNw4nvO4
[Strength test continued] At the track of Francorchamps the layers started to separate at 250Km/h with the Gopro mounted. Headbutting the cam on the straight might also have something to do with that. :D

comments.text: I haven't printed it yet, but to get a strong object you must print it on its side, with the mount facing up, otherwise the bond between the ball and the mount will be weak and you risk loosing your precious GoPro.
comments.author: Krafla

comments.text: Hi, how did you print this without the ball coming loose from the support structure around it after printing about 1cm heigh?
comments.author: pluisje

comments.text: Sorry I didn't mention I printed mine upside down with support. That way the ball is printed last and attached more firmly to the base. This way you won't have the issue with the ball coming loose from the support.

comments.text: I was wondering why the model was with the ball down, but good to know. My first attempt broke when I was fitting it to the bike, I'm printing another one with thicker walls & more fill now. If that fails as well I'll try it upside down. Thanks for the design!

Well-known both for its acknowledgment of San Jose's cultural heritage and for the fact that it strongly resembles fanged poop, the Plumed Serpent (Quetzalcóatl) is a cast stone sculpture designed by artist Robert Graham and commissioned by the city in 1994 The original sculpture, too, is a product of art and machines. It was cast using large pieces of CNC'd foam shaped from 3D data captured of the 11.5" tall clay original. My process was not nearly as artisanal; I took a number of photos with my DSLR, fed them into PhotoScan, and cleaned up the results in Blender. Even still, it's fascinating how technology continues to intersect with this ancient symbol, shepherding the past into the future. -NOS http://www.robertgraham-artist.com/civic_monuments/plumed_serpent.html http://www.sanjose.com/underbelly/unbelly/Sanjose/Quetzy/quetzy.html
You'll likely need supports in the mouth and under the tail.

title: FT952 200mw video Tx holder for Emax NightHawk 250

description.text:
If you build one, Please Post it!   
This is a simple mount for the FT952 200mw video Tx. this will allow you to easily add it to the Emax NightHawk frame. I printed it without support on a MakerBot Replicator 2 at 100 micron layer height with no support. clearances are pretty tight so that the VTx will stay secure. Happy printing!

You will need 2 x M3 bolts and 2 x M3 locking nuts to attach this to your quad. I also used 2 M3 washers on the under side to make the connection better with the locking nuts.  
I used 1 small Ziptie to secure the module to the holder. if the fit is too loose, you can add some double sided mounting tape under the module to take up space.  
Solid! Enjoy!
